text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with pumpkin cheesecake that's
right we're combining in America's
favorite cheese based desserts with
America's favorite gourd
sorry cucumbers and this came out so
delicious I can't believe nobody thought
of combining these before it really
works great so let me show you how to do
this the bad news is there's a lot of
ingredients the good news is it's super
easy to do so step one here we're going
to make a crumb crust and instead of the
traditional graham crackers we're going
to go with ginger snaps and I want you
use those thin dry hard ones you ate
when you were kid do not buy those fancy
good tasty ginger snaps
and we're going to throw those in a bag
and crush those down to a fine crumb if
you have a food processor use it this
took like 20 minutes in the bag broke
and was kind of annoying but eventually
I got her done so we're going to toss a
couple cups of those in a mixing bowl to
which we're going to add some flour some
brown sugar and some melted butter and
then we're going to take a spatula and
we're going to mix this thoroughly kind
of smashing it and mashing it against
the bottom of the bowl until it
basically resembles sand and it's not
really gonna hold together yet but
that's fine because we're going to add
one egg yolk and once we mix that up
with the spatula very well you should
have a nice pressable gingersnap crumb
crust alright and it's not going to be
wet it's still going to be very sand
like but if you squeeze it together like
that it will clump which is perfect so
we're gonna set that aside while we prep
our springform pan that's your standard
ten inch by three inch
cheesecake pan I'm going to spray that
thoroughly with some canola we're going
to dump in our crumbs we're going to
even them out of course because why
won't you and I like to go up the sides
about an inch and then you're going to
want to press that down firmly on the
bottom of course and if you went up the
sides a little bit you'll want to go
around and press with your fingers
around the outside around the outside
around the outside okay so our crumbs
are in and firmly pressed at that point
we're going to place this on a piece of
heavy-duty foil and kind of press it
tight and bring it up against the sides
and then we're going to place that in a
large roasting pan and because we are
going to use a water bath that foil is
going to add a little extra layer
protection although I've never had a
problem with water getting into the pan
so this is probably unnecessary but
we'll do it anyway some of us get paid
by this step and then we can just let
that sit there while we make our filling
which like any great cheesecake is going
to start with cream cheese so I got four
packages I'm using the one from the city
that the roots are from and to that
we're going to add some brown sugar and
white
sugar and we'll bring that over to our
stand mixer that has the paddle
attachment and all we need to do for
this step is simply cream those together
so start off slow so it doesn't all fly
out come on stay in there stay in there
all right I think we're okay and once it
gets mixed in you can turn it up to high
speed and just mix that until light and
fluffy
at which point we're going to stop
scrape down that paddle and simply
reserve that until needed so in another
bowl we're going to add two cans of
pumpkin and puree pure pumpkin the
ingredient list should literally just
say pumpkin if it says anything else
don't use it and then we're going to
spice that up with the traditional
pumpkin pie spices including cinnamon
some ground ginger some allspice some
freshly grated nutmeg and by the way to
the people emailing me I have no idea
why I say it like that
it's a mystery we're also going to need
a nice big pinch of salt as well as some
vanilla extract and some bourbon whiskey
oh yeah that's optional but you should
add it and then we're ready for the eggs
we're going to add four large whole eggs
plus two large egg yolks and we're going
to grab our whisk and start mixing this
up and any time I grab a whisk I always
ask myself what did you forget and in
this case it was the flour so I stopped
threw in some flour resumed mixing and
we're going to keep mixing that until
completely smooth and then the final
step go ahead and grab your cream cheese
mixture dump it in and mix it until
absolutely and thoroughly smooth it's
going to take a minute but you don't
want any lumps of cream cheese because
you'll see little white dots in your
finished cheesecake and of course I made
this harder on myself by using cold
cream cheese instead of room-temperature
cream cheese which would mix in a lot
easier so please follow the directions
on the blog post where I say to use room
temperature and once you're confident
that is absolutely smooth we can go
ahead and pour that into our pan and
then we don't want to give it the old
tap a tap or the traditional old shake
of sheikha
but we are going to spatulate this in
the center which is going to kind of
settle everything from the inside out
and once that's been done we're going to
carefully pick this up yes it is filled
almost all the way to the top so be
careful we're going to carefully place
that in the center of a preheated 325
degree oven and I mentioned we're going
to do water bath but that's much easier
if you pour the water in with the pan
already in the oven so I'm gonna pour in
my steaming hot water they say it should
be boiling but my tap water is so hot
it's almost boiling we're going to pour
that in and we want
to come about halfway up the pan and
once we've done that we'll push that
back in close the door and we're going
to bake that at 325 for about an hour
and 45 minutes approximately and I like
to start checking at about an hour and a
half and I definitely like to use a
thermometer to check that's why you're
going to see a hole in the top we're
going to shoot for an internal
temperature of about 160 and the mixture
is not going to be totally set it's
definitely going to have a little jiggle
in the center if you cook your
cheesecake until it's set it will be
overcooked and I'm going to give you a
ton more info on the blog on how to tell
yours is done so go check that out at
that point we're going to turn off the
heat we're going to open the oven door
to let most of the heat out at this
point I like to go around the edge with
a thin knife which will help that
surface not crack as it contracts and
once that's done we're going to go ahead
and close the door but not all the way
we're going to leave the door ajar and
we're just going to let that Cheesecake
slowly cool in that warm oven for one
hour and theoretically that's going to
prevent cracks so I let mine cool an
hour like that I pulled it out and you
can see absolutely no cracks the only
blemish that stupid thermometer mark but
I did that for you and again you got to
check the post for that bonus internal
temperature info at this point you can
remove it from the pan and just set it
on the counter and let it cool
completely see it's probably still a
little warm so let's sit there for a
couple hours
once it's room temperature throw some
foil on it throw in the fridge and chill
it completely completely before you try
to unmold it you cannot and don't want
to cut a warm cheesecake besides warm
cheesecake tastes terrible so let it
cool and if you do leave this overnight
don't be surprised if the next morning
you have some pumpkin sweat nothing to
worry about totally normal take a paper
towel and wipe off a little that
perspiration and then simply unlatch
that spring carefully remove the ring
and you're ready to slice and serve your
pumpkin cheesecake check that out for no
line cook that's not bad and of course
I'm gonna give a little dollop of
whipped cream that's optional unless
you're taking pictures then it's
mandatory and then maybe for a little
visual interest some green pumpkin seeds
you may remember that garnish from every
single pumpkin recipe I've ever done and
that's it
lots of ingredients took a long time but
super easy to make and a taste and
texture just absolutely stunning like a
perfect hybrid between a pumpkin pie and
a cheesecake the flavors like 75%
pumpkin pie 25% G
cake the texture the other way around
like 75% cheesecake 25% pumpkin pie if
you add that up it comes up to 100%
delicious so whether you're making this
as a special Thanksgiving dessert or
just any time you want something sweet
that tastes incredible
I really hope you give this a try head
over to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
